com.github.valid8j.pcond.core.fluent

Interface Checker<V extends Checker<V,T,R>,T,R>

  • Type Parameters:
    V - The type of the checker.
    T - The type from which the target value is transformed.
    R - The type of the target value.
    All Superinterfaces:
    Matcher<V,T,R>, Statement<T>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    AbstractObjectChecker<V,T,R>, BooleanChecker<T>, ComparableNumberChecker<V,T,N>, DoubleChecker<T>, FloatChecker<T>, IntegerChecker<OIN>, ListChecker<T,E>, LongChecker<OIN>, ObjectChecker<OIN,E>, ShortChecker<T>, StreamChecker<T,E>, StringChecker<T>, ThrowableChecker<T,E>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    BooleanChecker.Impl, Checker.Base, DoubleChecker.Impl, FloatChecker.Impl, IntegerChecker.Impl, ListChecker.Impl, LongChecker.Impl, ObjectChecker.Impl, ShortChecker.Impl, StreamChecker.Impl, StringChecker.Impl, ThrowableChecker.Impl

    public interface Checker<V extends Checker<V,T,R>,T,R>
extends Matcher<V,T,R>, Statement<T>

    An interface that defines methods to check a target value. By default, calls of checking methods defined in this and sub-interfaces of this interface will be a conjunction of them. To make it a disjunction, call Matcher.anyOf().

    User-exposing methods to check values in this method names should be progressive and its objective so that they can follow "to be" or "satisfies" in an English sentence.

      • not

      • $

        default Statement<Object> $()

        When you use an assertion method that accepts multiple statements (Statement), it requires all the elements in the array (varargs) should have the same generic parameter type. However, you sometimes want to check multiple types at once. By calling this method for every statement building method calling chain, you can address the compilation error.

        class Example {
  public static void main(String... args) {
    assert all(
       objectValue(arg[0]).isNotNull().$(),
       objectValue(new Example()).isNotNull().$(),
       ...
    );
  }
}
        Returns:
        A statement for java.lang.Object type.
